description: From Middle English pursuen, from Anglo-Norman pursure, poursuire etc., from Latin pr≈çsequor (though influenced by persequor). Doublet of prosecute.

verbs.description: pursue (third-person singular simple present pursues, present participle pursuing, simple past and past participle pursued)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To follow urgently, originally with intent to capture or harm; to chase. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To follow, travel down (a particular way, course of action etc.). [from late 14th c.]
examples: Her rival pursued a quite different course.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To aim for, go after (a specified objective, situation etc.). [from late 14th c.]
(transitive) To participate in (an activity, business etc.); to practise, follow (a profession). [from 15th c.]
(intransitive) To act as a legal prosecutor.
